description: Display legal considerations and compliance information in a structured grid layout

mainTitle.default: Legal Considerations and Compliance for Business Quotations

leadText.default: While quotations aren't always legally binding documents, they can become enforceable contracts under certain conditions. Understanding the legal implications helps protect your business and maintain professional relationships.

default.title: When Quotations Become Binding
default.description: In most jurisdictions, a quotation becomes a legally binding contract when formally accepted by the client within the validity period. Acceptance can be verbal, written, or implied through actions (such as making a deposit). Once accepted, neither party can unilaterally change the terms without mutual agreement.
listItems: Written acceptance via email or signed document
Verbal agreement recorded or witnessed
Partial payment or deposit made
Commencement of work based on quotation

default.title: Essential Legal Disclaimers to Include
default.description: Protect your business by including clear statements about:
listItems: Price validity period and expiration date
Circumstances affecting pricing (material costs, exchange rates)
Force majeure clauses for unforeseen events
Limitation of liability statements
Governing law and jurisdiction for disputes
Intellectual property rights
Confidentiality agreements

default.title: Tax Compliance Requirements
default.description: Ensure your quotations comply with local tax regulations:
listItems: Include tax registration numbers (GST/VAT/EIN)
Clearly state whether prices include or exclude taxes
Specify applicable tax rates for each item
Follow country-specific format requirements
Include harmonized system codes for international trade

default.title: Record Keeping Obligations
default.description: Many jurisdictions require businesses to maintain quotation records for tax and audit purposes:
listItems: Keep copies of all quotations issued (accepted and declined)
Maintain records for required period (typically 5-7 years)
Store digital copies in unalterable format
Include in regular backup procedures
Ensure accessibility for tax audits
